Alternatively use our A-Z index.
Combined degrees in the Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences allow you to study two subjects as part of the same degree programme.
With 30 subjects and over 300 combinations to pick from, you can choose a degree that enables you to develop your interests and strengths in multiple areas. Choose from joint (50/50) or major/ minor (75/25) and language options.
Our most popular type of combined degree. Perfect if you’re equally interested in two subjects.
We offer select combinations on a major/ minor basis. 75% of your credits come from your major subject and 25% from your minor.
With eight languages to choose from, you can build on existing knowledge or study something new. 50/50 and 75/25 options are available.
Why study a combined degree? Learn more about some of the benefits of studying two subjects.
Check tuition fees for all available degree combinations.

pages.content:
[HEADING] Applications for 2025 are now open
[HEADING] How to apply
[HEADING] *Applying for an MRes or PhD?
Popular pages:
Undergraduate

                        Postgraduate
                    

                        PhD
                    
Accommodation
Research

                        International students
Alternatively use our A-Z index.
To make it easier for you to apply for your master's programme (excluding MRes programmes*), we’ve introduced a simplified application process for final-year University of Liverpool undergraduates.
We're also applying flexible entry requirements so that you can apply for most of our master’s programmes with a 2:2 in your undergraduate degree (please note that there are some exemptions to this). And, provided you meet the entry criteria, we’ll guarantee your place for the next academic year!
1. As you already have a student record, you can simply apply by logging in with your MWS username and password. If you've already graduated, you'll have to apply using the  University of Liverpool Application Portal.2. The application only takes five minutes to complete, compared to approximately 30 minutes when you apply via the standard application portal.3. You can apply for up to two programmes.4. There is no need to add any supporting documents.  If we do need anything further from you, we will contact you directly to request it.
5. Finally, we will make you an offer to study your chosen programme within five days of you receiving your degree results, provided you meet the entry requirements.  Please note that where you don't meet the entry requirements, the academic department that you’re applying to may contact you to discuss your application and/or they may ask you to attend an interview or complete an additional assessment.
Please note that if the master's course that you're applying for doesn't appear on the simplified application form above you will need to apply via the University of Liverpool Application Portal.
If you want to apply for one of our MRes (Master of Research) or postgraduate research programmes, you’ll need to do that via he University of Liverpool Application Portal.
For MRes applications, visit liverpool.ac.uk/study/postgraduate-taught/applying/.
For PhD applications, visit liverpool.ac.uk/study/postgraduate-research/how-to-apply/.

[HEADING] Sport Liverpool Performance Programme
Popular pages:
Undergraduate

                        Postgraduate
                    

                        PhD
                    
Accommodation
Research

                        International students
Alternatively use our A-Z index.
The University is pleased to be able to offer scholarships to talented athletes competing at national and regional levels.
Our mission is to nurture and provide the optimal environment for athletes to achieve their goals and thrive in university life. We can help you reach your full potential, on and off the field of competition.
Two support packages are available:
The range of support across both programmes includes:
A very limited number of grants, worth up to £3,500, are available through the High Performance Athlete Programme.

This bursary is available to UK University of Liverpool graduates who are progressing to a standard master's course, including MRes programmes, within two years of graduation from their undergraduate degree.
UK University of Liverpool graduates who have graduated in the last two years and are progressing to a standard master's course, including MRes programmes, in 2025/26.
Graduates must have been in receipt of the University's Widening Access Award during their undergraduate studies i.e.
Please note that students in receipt of any of the above awards at UG level would not be able to concurrently hold the University of Liverpool Graduate Loyalty Advancement Scholarship.
Students in receipt of the Postgraduate Opportunity Award cannot concurrently hold the University of Liverpool Graduate Loyalty Advancement Scholarship.
They must be beginning a new full-time or part-time postgraduate taught master’s programme (including MRes programmes) in academic year 2025/26. ii) They must be an alumnus or alumna of the University of Liverpool having completed an undergraduate degree on the Liverpool campus no earlier than session 2023/24. iii) They must have been in receipt of one of the University’s Widening Access Awards during their period of undergraduate studies at the University of Liverpool.
Full-time taught postgraduate students will receive the award for one year.  For part-time students the award will be paid at a rate pro-rata to the ratio of their programme fee to the full-time programme fee.
Students will not be eligible for the Postgraduate Opportunity Bursary in any year when they are receiving external sponsorship (e.g. payment of programme fees by a registered company or other external sponsor) of value equal to or greater than the value of the award. The value of the award will refer to the pro-rata award where the student is registered on a part-time basis.
Applicants will be automatically selected based on their previous receipt of any of the current widening access awards at UG level within the last two academic years prior to commencement of their PGT study.
No separate application is necessary.

Undergraduate

                        Postgraduate
                    

                        PhD
                    
Accommodation
Research

                        International students
Alternatively use our A-Z index.
The John Lennon Memorial Scholarships were set up by a trust fund endowed in the University for the provision of scholarships in the memory of John Lennon by his family. The award is intended to support students from Merseyside who might be in financial need and enhance, among other things, awareness of global problems and environmental issues.
There are two competition streams for applicants and each applicant may enter only one:
If you are a current research student, the amount will be £12000 per annum until the end of the third year of full-time registration when you should go submission pending. For example, if you are starting your second year, you will get two years of funding. This is pro rata’d for part time study. As a rule, we don’t fund the final year of study.
If you are a current or prospective Home postgraduate (taught and research), either born in or with very strong family connections to Merseyside and who have academic offer from the University of Liverpool, you are eligible to apply. The award is available to all subject areas studied on the main University campus. It does not have to be an unconditional offer at this point.
The John Lennon Memorial Scholarship is available to all prospective and current Home (UK) students. Please note that international students are not eligible for application to this scholarship.
In accordance with the donor's intentions, priority will be given to applicants whose permanent residence is Merseyside or who have a significant period of residence (independent of study). All prospective postgraduate students must have accepted an offer to study at the University of Liverpool. Awards will be made on the basis of financial need and academic merit, and applicants should demonstrate an active and interest in global, community and environmental issues.
If you are a current PGR student, the award is available from 1 October until the end of the third year of your registration (or part time equivalent).
Please note that the Scholarships Sub-Committee may insert additional eligibility criteria to the list above. For example, the Scholarship Sub-Committee may target some awards at particular disciplines or levels, if deemed appropriate.
In order to apply for this award you will be required to complete a John Lennon Memorial Scholarship application form (Word, 0.1MB). Please ensure you complete all the sections, especially the reference section.
The deadline for applications is Friday 4 April 2025.
You will need to complete and submit the‌ form by email to the Secretary to the Scholarships Sub-Committee by email to scholarships@liverpool.ac.uk.
For all enquiries please email the Secretary to the Scholarships Sub-Committee.
• Taught postgraduate and MRes: A contribution towards tuition fees to a maximum of £4500 towards the fee for the academic year 2024/25
• Research postgraduate: A contribution towards fees and/or maintenance of up to £12000 per annum for up to 3 years subject to satisfactory progression and re-registration. Pro rata adjustments will be made for part time students over 5 years.

Alternatively use our A-Z index.
Find out how one of our Pre-sessional English courses can help you improve your English language skills to the required standard.
Some of our academic courses have English language requirements of IELTS 6.5 overall, with no component below 6.0, or equivalent.
If you want to join one of these courses but don't currently meet the English language requirements, don't worry. We can use your most recent IELTS score, or the equivalent score in selected other English language tests, to determine the length of Pre-sessional English course you require.
Your Pre-sessional English course may be available on campus or online. This depends on your most recent English language test and how long you need to study Pre-sessional English.
If you're using an IELTS Academic test to show your current English language proficiency, use the table below to check the course length you're likely to need.
Please note, this information is a guide only. If you're unsure about your current level of English language ability, please contact us for advice at elc@liverpool.ac.uk.
IELTS One Skill Retakes will be accepted if taken within 60 days of the original test.
It's not just IELTS we can use to assess your current English language ability.
If you've completed any of the other English language tests listed below, click the name of the test to see the length of Pre-sessional English course you're likely to require.
For LanguageCert Academic, the equivalent standard to IELTS 6.5 overall with no component below 6.0, is 70 overall, with no skill below 65.
For Pearson PTE, the equivalent standard to IELTS 6.5 overall with no component below 6.0, is 61 overall, with no component less than 59.
For Skills for English, the equivalent standard to IELTS 6.5 overall with no component below 6.0, is B2 Pass with Merit in all bands.
6 or 20 weeks: on campus
10 weeks: on campus and online options available
For the Oxford Test of English, the equivalent standard to IELTS 6.5 overall with no component below 6.0, is 136 or above overall, with no component below 126.
For Duolingo, the equivalent standard to IELTS 6.5 overall with no component below 6.0, is 120 overall, with no component below 105.
You'll be assessed in the skills of writing, reading, speaking and listening on a Pre-sessional English course.
To meet English language requirements of IELTS 6.5 overall, with no component less than 6.0, or equivalent, you’ll need to achieve an overall Pre-sessional English score of 50% or above. You'll also need to obtain a minimum score of 40% or above in each assessment.
If the English language requirements for your intended academic course aren't IELTS 6.5 overall, with no component below 6.0, or equivalent, the information on this page doesn't apply to you.
You should refer to the Pre-sessional English entry requirements that match the IELTS profile for your intended course.
• To study Pre-sessional English on campus, only secure English language tests (SELTs) are accepted
• To study online, your most recent English language test must have taken place face-to-face in a test centre, excluding Duolingo and LanguageCert Academic for which the home test is acceptable.
